title: Armoured companion
text:
Armoured companion (<a href="Polish%20language">Polish</a>: "Towarzysz pancerny" , plural: "towarzysze pancerni") was a medium-cavalryman in 16th to 18th century <a href="Poland">Poland</a>, named after their <a href="chainmail">chainmail</a> <a href="armor">armor</a>. These units were the second-most-important (and successful) <a href="cavalry">cavalry</a> in the Polish-Lithuanian army, after the <a href="Polish%20hussars">hussars</a>.
Most "pancerni" were recruited from the middle or lower classes of the Polish (or Lithuanian) <a href="nobility">nobility</a>. They were organized into companies, with each company (Polish: "<a href="Chor%C4%85giew%20%28military%20unit%29">chorągiew</a>" or "<a href="Rota%20%28formation%29">rota</a>") consisting of 60 to 200 horsemen.
Arms.
They used <a href="chainmail">chainmail</a> or <a href="mail%20and%20plate%20armour">bechter</a> armour to protect the upper body, <a href="vambrace">vambrace</a> sometimes with <a href="Gauntlet%20%28glove%29">gauntlets</a>, <a href="Secrete%20%28helmet%29">secretes</a> (rarely <a href="lobster-tailed%20pot%20helmet">lobster-tailed pot helmet</a>), <a href="buckler">buckler</a> shields, Polish <a href="sabre">sabre</a>, reflex <a href="Bow%20and%20arrow">bow</a>, <a href="gunpowder">gunpowder</a> weapons, (such as <a href="flintlock">flintlock</a> pistols, <a href="arquebus">arquebus</a> or <a href="muskets">muskets</a>, and early <a href="carabine">carabine</a>s). Earlier companies would sometimes be equipped with a <a href="horseman%27s%20pick">horseman's pick</a>, a short <a href="spear">spear</a>, or a <a href="lance">lance</a>. During the rule of king <a href="John%20Sobieski">John III Sobieski</a>, polearms became compulsory.
During the <a href="Middle%20Ages">Middle Ages</a>, under the rule of <a href="Mieszko%20I">Mieszko I</a> and <a href="Boles%C5%82aw%20I%20Chrobry">Bolesław I the Brave</a>, the name "pancerni" applied to the members of the duke's retinue. They were the wealthiest warriors in the Polish army, and as such, they could afford to wear sophisticated armour, most commonly chainmail. Their weapons included <a href="Knightly%20sword">arming swords</a>, <a href="axe">axe</a>s, spears, <a href="shields">shields</a>, strait <a href="Bow%20and%20arrow">bow</a>s, and <a href="nasal%20helmet">nasal helmet</a>s.
